title: Between 1 January 2018 and 31 December 2018, will an armed group from Zimbabwe engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Zimbabwe?

Mugabe is gone. I think there is a feeling of relief and hope. Let's hope it is justified.
I'm guessing the state will start a crackdown if there's any resistance following the removal from power of Robert Mugabe last year.
I do not know of serious publically available indicators for such events this year.
Zimbabwe looks to be improving post-Mugabe and I have read nothing pointing towards insurrection.

With a recent coup, new leadership, and a much-feared Emmerson Mnangagwa replacing Mugabe, a politically unstable Zimbabwe prepares for an election under possibly severely unfair conditions. The opposition leader was attacked, and there are concerns about the country's future. It doesn't seem likely, however, that this specific prediction will come to pass, as the coup was completed without any massive bloodshed and things look like they're going "okay" for now.  I'll update this forecast if any evidence arises that this country will respond to its somewhat rocky transition anything other than peacefully.  Factions are unlikely arise to defend an ousted leader in his 90s... the Crocodile, however, is another question....  Does he let elections go on fairly?  15% says this goes sour and he clamps down.
I think it will take a while for this country to fall apart - if it indeed does given there might be a positive change in the wind
The likelihood is low, unless it looks as though the Crocodile will not win the election.
No chance especially after peaceful ousting of Mugabe.
Short of a complete breakdown of government, deaths will remain well below 1,000.
currency stability should undermine armed conflict

Given the strong military involvement into the political ruling of the country is does not seem likely that there will be an all out conflict that will lead to mass killings in a systematic way. The only exception is strong military reaction against protests (hence 15%).

Theyâ€™ll give the new kleptocracy some space. South Africa too preoccupied by own kleptocracy to influence any change of course. China will help keep dissent in check given their investments/influence. And maybe - despite all the old hands - there will actually be a focus on broader economy in what should be a much better off country.

Zimbabwe already has had a quite peaceful change of government - as always, there will be some small reforms aiming at improving the situation of the population and the population itself will have to overcome its moments of inertia, before there is an even slight chance for the outbreak of any kind of violence.

Now that Mugabe is out, increased instability makes this somewhat more likely than in the past.

Things are getting better in Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe massacres will go down with the help of President MnangagwaI. I don't think more than 1K people will be killed. There will be violence but not to this level.

Lack of conflict resolution milestones and ongoing ethic inequalities fueling negative emotions among groups. This is due to ineffective communication caused by incomplete bilateral perception deficits.
We have the first administration post coup - always dicey business stabilizing the country after an upheaval.
